Great brunch on the rooftop today! The jalapeño and horseradish infused vodka Bloody Mary's were great. The eggs Benedict and grits were tasty. No wait and a great way to kick off a Steeler Sunday. The staff was great.

I've only ever come here for the rooftop bar, and to be honest--it's not the best rooftop downtown. The drinks and appetizers are good, and decently priced for happy hour (M-F, 5-7). The rooftop space is limited, so don't plan on getting a seat!

A nice place for dinner.  We rolled in in shorts and t shirts, and they were super nice to us despite the fact that we were obviously quite underdressed.  The setting is very modern, there's a small menu of well executed dishes. The prices were also very good for the quality of the food.   It didn't blow any of our minds, but we were all really happy with the food, service and atmosphere. The rooftop patio is also pretty great.

I so really like this place. Is it a bit overpriced? Yes. But the experience of downtown and a show is worth the splurge. I almost always get the pork shank which is pretty damn good. You can split it with an up charge which I recommend because it's Flintstone-like. Had the cheese plate on an afternoon with a bottle wine for happy hour with friends on the rooftop. Nice for Pittsburgh with the limited amount of outdoor dining.

I went here on a first date and the atmosphere was nice but it had a strange seating arrangement. We were seated on the second floor and the tables were too high for my liking, made me feel like a child. The tables were also fairly long, making it a little difficult to have a conversation without feeling that everyone can hear.   My date ordered us the calamari appetizer and it was delicious! Later I had the chicken and I wasn't too impressed, a little dry but nothing too good or too bad.   I would like to try again.
Food is good, not great. Service is slow and the portions are small if truly hungry then I would look elsewhere.

My friend and I decided to try this place tonight before seeing a show at the Benedum. We had made a reservation for 5:30pm but we were stuck in traffic and running late. My friend called the hostess at the stand to let her know and she was very friendly. She thanked her for calling and said no problem we will hold your table. When we got there, we were seated right away and we were immediately served water at our table. Our server, Jordan came over to let us know the specials and answer any menu questions. She was very pleasant and knowledgeable about all of the food they offered and even made great suggestions for us when we weren't sure what to order. We ended up getting the Pinot Grigio sangria to drink. It was tasty and went down a little too smoothly lol. They also serve you an assortment of breads with infused oil which was my favorite part of the meal-so good!  We ordered the calamari appetizer to share and it was good but I wasn't crazy about the dipping sauces it came with.  My friend ordered the pork shank for her entree. She absolutely loved her meal, said the meat was tender and flavorful and falling off the bone. She enjoyed the dipping sauce it came with as well. I had the seafood bucatini. I did love that the noodles were cooked Al dente. The sugar snap peas were also cooked perfectly-not too raw but not mushy, just right. The shrimp, mussels and crab were also cooked well. While I did enjoy my entree for the most  part, it wasn't really over the top and definitely not the best meal I've had downtown. I was expecting more. I do have to say that the service here was definitely wonderful. Our server was very attentive and friendly and so were the other employees. We may return for dessert and after dinner drinks but there are just so many other restaurants in Pittsburgh to try.

Had a terrible experience here when having an early rooftop dinner on a Saturday. The service was neglectful and it took almost an hour to get our food, almost making us late for the show we were on our way to. The food was average at best.

I'm torn - came for a yelp elite event a few months ago and it deserved a 4-5 star review.  Went tonight (last night it's open) and was just ok.  Wine selection was fab - service was great - the food we ordered was just ok.  It is a great location, especially if you're coming for a show at the Benedum but sad to say it's closing tonight so won't be around for future outings :-(

I was very disappointed. The service was sloppy and the time between courses was forever. The soup came cold (sent it back) and we ordered crab cakes and they were mushy and ground to dust. No taste but darn expensive. I would not go back. There are a LOT better downtown.

We happened to come across Six Penn as it was near our hotel. Very cool spot with a nice urban interior and a fantastic rooftop bar. Admittedly we didn't eat here, but the menu looked good although a bit on the pricey side. The drinks were great though. An extensive selection of beers and nice atmosphere which is all together what we were looking for.

Vegetarian perspective-  Best vegan prix fixe dinner I have had in Pittsburgh. I specifically choose this restaurant for restaurant week because it had a vegan option (in addition to steak and fish).  Ambiance is bustling but cozy. Great location of you are catching a show. Street parking is hard but there is a parking garage right across the street. I enjoyed my $6 nojito (since I was DD). The prix fixe started with a yummy root vegetable salad with a variety of beets, radishes, and carrots. I also enjoyed the somewhat random sweet cookie type bar which was part of the salad. The star of the show was the Moroccan tangine. Steaming hot with excellent flavors and beans as well as a house made naan, this was my favorite vegetarian dish in the past 6 months of dining out! There was enough to take home for a second meal! I was also pleasantly surprised by the vegan chocolate mouse, beautifully presented and I liked the subtle coconut milk flavor. The dish was a bit overwhelmed by the amount of berries.  Service and pace were excellent, we would be happy to return again!

I wasn't sure what to expect when I went but I would have to say I was really blown away. The service and atmosphere was great and the food is fantastic! It's definitely more for adults than for kids. I highly recommend if you get to talk to the manager David ask for his recommendations. Really knows his stuff and has a passion for his work!

Great evening with friends from out of town.  Situated in the middle of the cultural district.  The highlight was watching the snow fall (our friends are from the south) during our fabulous meal.  Jordyn was an attentive server and her recommendations for dinner choices were outstanding.  The bartender "Sugar" was also attentive.  Thank you for a wonderful evening.

Went there for restaurant week last time and to this day, my husband still talks about the pork shank he ate. Out. Of. This. World. I can't even remember exactly what I ordered, that's how good his pork was. I think I got some type of risotto, which was also fantastic. Located right downtown and being pretty busy for restaurant week, we weren't able to get a table upstairs, so we sat at the lower level. We both enjoyed how you can see the chefs cooking and kept us entertained while we waited for our meals (which wasn't long). Our waiter was friendly and knowledgeable and we were in and out in an hour, tops.  I did not think there were a lot of menu options, but from our experience, everything we ordered was amazing. This is a great spot if you're catching a show downtown and don't have a lot of time to grab something to eat, yet it still gives you the feel of a nice restaurant and I was able to enjoy my meal without feeling rushed. I would definitely go back.

I have to go with consensus here - this place is good, but has a few gaping holes. If you're adventurous, go for it.  If you're trying to impress a group -- my reservations were for a work group of 10 aged 26-60 -- there are enough "ehhh" dishes on the menu that you'd wish you'd gone elsewhere.     Stay away from the Beet Salad.  They say it has it's in a balsamic vinagrette.  All I got were oil-soaked lettuce leaves (BP?  Is that you?) and some hidden beets.  It was almost tasteless.

Ate here once for lunch.   Not bad, upscale atmosphere, very limited menu.  There wern't a ton of people there but yet it seemed to take them a while to get us the food.  It was worth the try, maybe I will go again and maybe not.  I had the pulled pork.  It was good but not super filling and a little pricey for the size

Good place, I enjoyed the dinner menu more then the lunch. Service is very good, I wasn't 100% thrilled with my lunch choice and they took it off the bill no problem. Desert was great! Rooftop is the place to sit if you go here!

While some of the reviews "knock" this place, I really disagree as we were friendly greeted, quickly accommodated, and finely served.  Plus, the food was top-notch - which is what you want, right?  Our waiter was more than happy to meet our time constraint needs to make our show at nearby Heinz Hall - so drinks, apps, and child dinners got to the table swiftly and full of flavor.  The adult entrees arrived shortly thereafter and were both delicious and well portioned. While there is a small menu, it was still difficult to choose our grub as most items looked pretty darn good.  All said, its good eats in a vibrant atmosphere.  Just vibrant enough to squeeze in a second cocktail before scurrying out the door.    So, if you're looking for a meal before a nearby show, I'd recommend this place in a second. If you're looking for solid cocktails once the curtains go down, I'd recommend this place, too.  We'll certainly be back...whether its showtime or just because...Six Penn is a winner!

I frequent Six Penn, mostly for lunch. They recently did some renovating in the kitchen and, from today's visit, some deep cleaning.  Now don't get me wrong, this by no means a dirty restaurant, but I did notice that the light fixtures particularly gleam since they reopened after a few days respite.   Sadly, I must report that the glorious calamari po' boy is no more. I went periodically for the tender tendrils of calamari and the slightly tangy aioli. Please, please, PLEASE bring it back!! My server said many other guests have asked about its sad departure.  Based on other Yelp reviews, I'm not the only one who loved the po' boy!!

Wow, what a difference a few weeks and a second visit makes.  I eagerly anticipated returning to Six Penn after the first 5 star visit while traveling to Pittsburgh on business.   This visit was less than stellar.   The menu had changed which is understandable, although I was looking forward to ordering the brussel sprouts that I had during the previous visit, but I guess those were a part of the winter menu as was the deconstructed wedge salad.   There was not much that interested me on the "Spring" menu so I proceeded to order a la carte.   I ordered the flash fried calamari and rock shrimp, side of parmesan rosemary fries and a side of french green beans.   The calamari and rock shrimp were not very crispy, kinda greasy and had no flavor.  There was lots of calamari and very few shrimp.   The fries were just luke warm with very little parmesan cheese and no rosemary flavoring.  The french green beans were a complete "miss' for me.  Steamed whole green bean, dressed in an herb vinagrette with grape halves and whole toasted hazelnuts.   The vinagrette had very little flavor and the grapes and hazelnuts just didn't belong.  I left very disappointed, especially compared to my first visit.

I brought my parents here for brunch after a show and I was so disappointed!!!  First off let me begin by saying this is such a great location and visually awesome restaurant. We have been to 6 Penn in the past (4 years ago) and maybe their evening menu is better or maybe they have just gone down hill??  Missing the Burgh we just moved back and ended up here hoping for a great brunch.  I have to start off by saying don't believe the menu.   Banana Foster French toast.... This must have made me the most angry..... Sliced bananas on French toast dusted with confectionary sugar is a JOKE and a disgrace to the name banana foster. How hard is it to toss some bananas in a sauté pan with some butter, brown sugar, and a bit of rum??? After all that is what banana foster is!  So you can pay 12 bucks for the mere idea of banana foster but not the real thing.    I ordered a monte cristo sandwich and it was suppose to come with maple syrup. I was looking forward to that flavor profile of having something savory and sweet maple syrup as a condiment. They brought me regular table syrup not maple syrup .....again don't believe the menu ....you get to pay for the idea of maple syrup just not the real thing. The sandwich itself was dry leathery and had a funky taste....not good eats!  The home fries were dried up cubes that appeared to be deep fried? Definitely not home fries. Save yourself a lot of money and be nice to your taste buds...go to a diner for brunch not here.
If you like over cooked cold eggs with cold steak for breakfast it's a place to go! High price with horrible food, slow service. It took 45 min to get our food for breakfast!

Living downtown I have the distinct privilege of being able to eat at great and not so great restaurants on a regular this leads to a bit of a foodie malaise as I am inundated with the good and the bad frequently. Then a night like tonight happens! Welcome to the trendy Six Penn Kitchen! I walked in without a reservation waiting for the inevitable "do you have a reservation" with the slight eye roll and pretentiousness that comes with that loaded question. Instead I was greeted warmly at the door with a "good evening". I let them know I didn't have a reservation but was hoping to grab a table. They very politely let me know that it would be approximately fifteen minutes to reset a table or we could choose to sit at a high top table without the wait. Let the fun begin! My party of three sat at a high top in the bar area and were promptly approached by the bartender asking if we would like a drink. He took our order with ease and I threw him a curve ball. I asked for a drink I had experienced earlier in the week for the first time and man it was good. Unfortunately he hadn't heard of it before but instead of say nope, sorry, or HUH he politely let me know he didn't know the drink then hit me with a few popular ones he could nail. I asked for my fall back drink I LOVE the Moscow Mule which he said he could do without the copper cup and I was good with that! I'll tell you this much no copper cup didn't mess up his mules trip to Moscow one bit quite a tasty drink.   On to our table which was situated nicely in a beautifully appointed dinning area near the open view kitchen. I don't know who decorated and designed this space but they are brilliant! The lighting was bright enough to be cheery but dimmed enough to make for a potential romantic setting for a date or a nice dinner with your family. The kitchen is a lively, teeming view which gives a taste of trendy awesome but also feels a bit like watching Hell's Kitchen live and your getting the food. The volume is superb not loud so you can speak with your table without raising your voice and not quiet so you feel like you're eating at a pretentious swank establishment where grabbing the wrong fork may lead to snickers and pointing. So the atmosphere of this cool and upbeat place immediately grabs me and sets me down a path to what would become possibly the best dinning experience I've had living in Downtown Pittsburgh. Our server David was prompt, polite, professional and in a true sign of a great server eased us into our dinning experience. He gave us time to peruse the menus was unobtrusive and there when we had a question.  On to the good stuff... THE FOOD!!! So I'm not sure why or how this place ended up with a three star!!!  We ordered the Flash Fried Calamari & Shrimp as an appetizer. As our food came to the table our server kindly introduced us to the plate from the main ingredients along with the great sauces provided. MAN it was GOOD!!! The chef and his crew made sure that the calamari and shrimp were the stars of this appetizer which lead to a tender, moist, and lightly breaded mound of scrumptiousness. What a way to kick off a dinner! What made the meal even better was watching and listening to the Executive Sous-Chef de Cuisine Corey Hughes. He directed the kitchen like a WWII field general maintaining the smooth troop movements and precise battle field execution. He deftly controlled the pass ensuring that only the best was leaving his kitchen to tickle the guests palates. I thank you sir for your deft touch it made this moment in culinary time suspend, twist, and turn on my taste buds like mmmmm yumminess! Then the entree's reach the table with the elegance of Cinderella descending to the dance floor to meet prince charming. Once landed in front of our eyes the entree's stood there gorgeously plated screaming for forks, knives and the gnashing of our terrible teeth!  We ordered the "signature" Cracklin Pork Shank, Gourmet Burger, and Buffalo Mac N' Cheese.   HOLY CRUD, OMG, ARE YOU KIDDING ME!!!! The burger my wife ordered looked amazing and my wife couldn't put it down. According to her this 8oz. burger was juicy with a crown of ham and egg which left her sorry it was gone. My daughter let me steal a bite of her Buffalo Mac N' Cheese again the food was stuck on awesome. The bite I had was cheesy real cheesy and instead of just tasting cheese there was a plethora of other subtleties then the real surprise twist some heat oh yeah some good heat that made this cheesy, ooey, gooeyness just right! On to the dish I took a chance on and I am so, so, so glad I did. It was listed on the menu in their "Signature" section. Well let me tell you something SIGNATURE INDEED!!!! I thought I needed a knife to attack this huge portion of meat. To my surprise again the meat fell off the bone quite literally fell off the bone. It was moist, perfect, melt in your mouth goodness.

I come here every time I have tickets to a nice event nearby, usually at the Heinz theatre. It is always a good choice and I've always left feeling very satisfied. Their drinks menu is extensive and last time I went, I tried the Jamaican Me Ginger cocktail, which I highly recommend! My table and I also ordered the Chickpea Cakes, which exceeded my expectations. I got the Hudson Valley Duck Breast entree. The duck was very good and the meat was so tender. The gnocchi, however, tasted a bit bland, and I ended up leaving the majority of it on the plate. Nonetheless, it was still a good meal!  I highly recommend this restaurant!

Fabulous food, great wine, amazing location...this was an over the top event. Locally grown food was featured throughout the evening.   The space was a bit crowded and loud, however it was fun talking the the local farmers and wine merchants. I was particularly impressed by Penn's Corner, their food is great and they were very friendly.   Heather from Southern Wines was very knowledgeable and offered a great Tempranillo and a wonderful Chardonnay.  Lots of great food, interesting conversation and fantastic wine all made for a fun evening.

We enjoyed one of the last warm nights of the year on the rooftop terrace here. They don't take reservations for the terrace, so we were lucky to get a table immediately. We had a few appetizers, of which the pizza and cheese & charcuterie plate stood out for me. The mussels were OK, didn't try the chicken wings but they looked good too. For main I had the New York strip with brussels sprouts and mash. The meat was cooked as I asked for and really good. The brussels sprouts were slightly too crunchy and lacked seasoning. Biggest struggle was finding a good red wine. The glas of Californian cabernet I ordered was way too cold and not my taste at all. The pinot noir from Chile was better but a bit light on colour and taste for that grape variety. The service was good and attentive.
We were exploring the city and decided to stop in...we opted for the roof top seating and loved it.  Food, service and drinks were all GREAT!!!  The roof top seating was fun!!!  It was a great time!

My wife and I love when we stumble on a great place!  We went for Sunday Brunch. The menu had everyone covered. sweet, savory, spicy and traditional. The food was great. The Smoked Bloody Mary was even better! Too bad they only make that on Sundays. If you are stuck in a Hotel downtown, don't settle for a powdered eggs and  dry white toast. Get out and try it! Happy hour was great too.

SixPenn Kitchen is by far one of my favorite places in Pittsburgh. I have been a fan of this place since it opened and it only gets better. My friend and I go to SixPenn every year for our birthday dinner, and any chance I get to get in a meal here before a theater show, I do.   Now, my favorite picks on their menu had always been their calamari appetizer, and their pork shank entree. Both TO DIE for. The pork shank dish is a staple and it's one of the items that never change off of the menu. Eleven months ago, I decided to switch over to a plant based diet. I don't eat the calamari or pork shank anymore (although I still recommend them for their fabulousness!), now my go-to staple dish is their falafel. It's AMAZING! They have a great wine and specialty drink list to choose from, and the desserts never disappoint. The best part of the end of the meal are their homemade peppermint patties that come with your check.  I was at SixPenn Kitchen last night for a networking event with my young professional group. They accommodated us with the upstairs bar area, and blocked it off for our 50+ person event. The cheese tray and dessert trays were a perfect addition for our guests as well.  Whether you're stopping in for a nice dinner before a show, hosting a private party, or even a networking event, SixPenn fits every situation. If you've never been, add it to your bucket list of places to go in Pittsburgh!

Sadly, Six Penn is still stumbling after their great beginning under Keith Fuller. No innovations in the menu for a long time, poor quality control in the kitchen, and indifference have brought down a promising restaurant. Does anyone at Eat And Park corporation read Yelp?

Chic decor, extremely friendly service, very accommodating and fresh food.  Why only three stars?  The food didn't make me say "Mm-mm."  Tried several items since we were a large group and all were good but almost basic diner flavors.  Not a bad thing...just not a "you must go" type of place.  Nevertheless they were very accommodating and even hooked me up with a side dish of the buffalo mac-n-cheese since a really wanted to try it.

My co-workers and I had heard about this place and we were anxious to give it a try.  It's a bit of a walk from work (the Federal Building), so we decided what better weather than a beautiful October day in the 'Burgh to take a little stroll over here?    The food here is pretty decent, but I'd have to say it was a little pricey.  In all fairness though, they do have interesting selections here--much better than your standard "burgers-to-go" places.  Most sandwiches run around $10.00 each.  Entrees run somewhat more.  They do have a roasted pizza with mozzerella, basil and roasted tomatoes that sounded tempting.  I tried the "Turkey Bobby" which is turkey breast, bread stuffing, cranberry sauce & mayo on ciabatta.    But this place gets very busy around lunchtime and it seems that they get very overwhelmed here.  It's better to go between 1pm and 2pm for a late lunch like we did.    They  serve dinner here and brunch too.  It's probably better to go then.  They do have one brunch item that sounds interesting:  the breakfast sausage corndog.  It comes with 2 eggs, tater tots, and Hollandaise sauce.

My wife and I happened to go into Six Penn in a walk from parking to the theater because it was cold and windy.  Are we glad we did. Even though we just had wine and an appetizer of homemade pretzels, it all was delicious. We were directed upstairs to a table near the bar.  Our two waiters, Dan and Nikko, made us feel right at home and like we were old customers.  Their service was impeccable. Another surprise was that the manager, David Felaenato (spelling) came up to our table and made us welcome also.  Hey , nothing special about us, but he wanted to know where we lived, etc. Unbelievable short time. You can bet though, we will be back. BTW.....he told us we had parked in the parking garage across the street, the parking bill would have been $2. Go have a great time!

Six Penn Kitchen is closing. To me this is a great loss for the Pittsburgh Cultural District.   Good Food, Fast 'enough', convenient for all cultural events in the district, from Heinz Hall to the Benedum Center. Easy to establish reservations for pre, or post show. Great rooftop.  We don't eat here every trip to the district to see a show, ballet, symphony or what ever. But we do eat here often enough to value their contribution to the district.  We are going to badly miss Six Penn Kitchen. To me this is nothing short of a big loss for the cultural community.   Will anybody be so kind as to suggest an in-kind replacement that could be viewed as similar in cuisine??  Thanks Six Penn Kitchen, You are going to be missed!

I ate here while on business in Pittsburgh. I had wandered for hours all over Pittsburgh with the intention of casually stumbling upon a place for lunch. I had a little more trouble then I anticipated. It came to the point where I was desperate and about to jump off of one of the many bridges leaving downtown that I had crossed that day. Finally, to save me from the icy freezing february waters of the Allegheny River I stumbled across Six Penn.   The first thing I noticed: it's warm. At that point it was all I really cared about. I was seated immediately at a table for two and I sat facing the street so I could look out. My waiter was very friendly and came over immediately with water. I asked what he would suggest on the menu, but unfortunately suggested almost all meat plates (I'm not a big meat eater). That's when I saw under appetizers just what I wanted that day: A grilled cheese sandwich with tomato soup (9).  I also ordered a side of their homemade potato chips that I had seen someone else with (3).   Food: Deeeelish! The tomato soup was wonderful! Thick and creamy and hot and delicious. The grilled cheese sandwich: cheesy and buttery and an artery clogger, but just what I needed at the time. And the homemade potato chips were to die for. I also ordered desert, I got the brownie sundae (6.50). The desert was decent, but I was expecting a little more for the price, still very good though.  I recommend Six Penn Kitchen and if I ever go back I will try it for dinner as my waiter mentioned there was a separate dinner menu.

I will try and find the best things about our meal.. the service was good..the teenager said the burger was good..oh yeah, and the bread was good. The main courses were just not good at all. I had the Primavera pasta. I added about 2 Tbs of grated cheese and it still had no flavor. My man had the brisket gnocchi. That was not what we expected at all. It is about 5 (maybe baked) gnocchi's on top of a plate of brisket that was dry and other than the sauce pretty much flavorless. We had those three items, drank only water and the bill  with 20% tip was over $70. Definitely do not recommend.

The food is good. I've dined here many times over the past several years. Unfortunately, it does seem as though the service is going progressively downhill. I had dinner there last week with a party of four in advance of a show that we were attending. I actually selected Six Penn because they typically cater to theater-goers and thought that we would be able to enjoy our dinner and get to the show on time. Unfortunately, we had to wait for a very long time once we were seated to be visited by the waiter. We ordered our food the first time he came to the table, along with our drinks. We waited about 50 minutes for the food to come out, at which point, I ordered another drink. The second drink did not arrive until the check - which turned out to be the wrong check. As I quickly gulped down my prosecco and waited for the correct check, time was ticking away. By the time we finally settled the bill, we were late to the show. On top of that, the people in my party that ordered the special did not receive the meal as it was described, although they said it was good. There was a lot of confusion and I don't blame it on our waiter because it seems as though the entire restaurant was running in a state of chaos (even though it was only about 60% full when we arrived). It wasn't a horrible experience, but it was disappointing and probably not worth going back now that there are so many options in Pittsburgh.

Nice spot. Can have restaurant seating, at the small bar or hit up the rooftop when weather permits. Rooftop is a cozy space. Drinks are fair. About the same price as the rest of the bars in the area. Enjoyed my visit.

So, on a recent trip to Pittsburgh, we attempted to dine at Meat and Potatoes but they were completely booked.  We wanted something else in the area and ended up here.  We were a little scared at first because the reviews of this place are not super great.  That being said, we ended up having a really nice brunch!  We were seated in their balcony which was nice and quiet.  Even without a reservation, we were seated right away.  I ordered a blackberry bellini and it was delicious.  Our table also tried the beignets and they were yummy, too.  I ordered the traditional breakfast meal and it was really yummy and worked well with my low fodmap diet.  Everyone really liked their food.  The portions were healthy and appropriately priced.  Our server was super nice and helpful. He was a little slow in bringing us our checks at the end which soured the experience some but overall we had an enjoyable meal here and we were glad we stumbled in!

Never going back brunch was ok had steak and eggs service wasn't so great I'm a server  too in the downtown area and would never treat anybody the way I got treated here never ask how anything was if I need anything else barely seen the guy truthful it was a bit busy but nothing crazy and I usually will tip really really well but I felt like the guy wasn't worth 18 percent they suggested sorry won't be back !!

We had an early dinner here on Saturday with friends and family.  The service and food were just very below average unfortunately. We are used to attending very good eateries throughout our travels and based on the element and menu -- was very disappointed. I am not a complainer but a moajority of our food came out cold and there was nothing extraordinary about the meals. The server should not be handling large groups of patrons because she was very dissheveled and confused.

Stopped in without a reservation on a Saturday night. Received service right away and was seated at the seating overlooking the kitchen. These turn out to be my favorite seats at restaurants. Where you get to watch all the action as it happens. The food was on point as always. Service was fast... In and out because we had tickets to the hockey game. Less than 40 minutes and we were on our way. As always recommend this spot.

I went to Six Penn Kitchen a few months ago when the weather was still mild.   First of all, I love the location! I'm a big fan of Downtown Pittsburgh venues especially ones like this that have rooftop seating.   The food was great. I had duck which I never ate before this. I would not say that duck became my favorite kind of meat after this but it was prepared very well and the presentation was beautiful.   The staff was very attentive and kind. I had no problem getting sat along with my 7:30pm reservation on a Friday night I made via Open Table.  Parking is the only thing I really disliked but that is an overall problem in any major city.  I posted more about Six Penn Kitchen on my blog at http://midnightguru.com/place.php?id=73

This is my usual pre-theater spot. They have a great wine list, elevated comfort foods, and fantastic service. My friend and I received prompt service and made it to the Benedum center to see a show, with time to spare. My friend had the pork shank with roasted apples, applesauce, and mashed potatoes. She had ordered it during a previous visit and it was so good that she had to order it again! Due to my food allergies, I ordered the NY strip steak with mashed potatoes and plain green beans. They take food allergies into consideration and actually asked if any diners had any dietary restrictions when we made the reservation. However, they lost a star for me because I believe there was SOME cross-contamination with a utensil or pan while preparing my meal. I could smell garlic (I wasn't sure if it was my plate or my friend's) and had some stomach upset after the meal (I am obviously allergic to garlic). I likely shouldn't have eaten it, so that's partially my fault, but we were in a rush and I knew it wasn't something extremely serious. Thank goodness it was only one of my mild allergies and not a more severe one, but I will let the staff know to be more careful in the future.

The bar is in a beautiful building and the waiters were friendly and helpful but the food was just not very good for the price. Its very generic run of the mill food something you may expect at a decent restaurant but really nothing exciting on the menu nor anything I ate that was particularly well cooked. Overall an average experience but for the price there are much better places in the area

I live in the city and ordered an eggs Benedict to go. Stupid me for not checking the food because this is what I got. I called back to tell them about it and they offered me their house fries that were supposed to come with the meal. Shame on the chef for even plating that and calling it worth 18 dollars.

I came here for lunch with a coworker on Friday, the weekend of Memorial Day weekend. I had the Pennsylvania portobello sandwich with barley salad that was pretty good. My coworker had the grilled cheese sandwich and she also liked her lunch. Our biggest complaint was the wait time. We couldn't understand it because the restaurant really wasn't that busy. It seem like our server totally forgot about us. That's why I'm giving this review three stars.

This is a classy place, with a great roof deck and drink menu, as well as a creative entree menu overall.  And the whole time I'm there, I can't help but think:  "I can't believe that this is owned by Eat 'N Park.   I've been there for lunch and dinner, as well as just drinks.  All experiences have been positive.  One of my favorite things about Six Penn (besides the roof deck) is that you can book reservations online.  This makes it very easy/convenient for business lunches.   For lunch, I'd recommend the Cuban Quesadilla, which is light enough not to make you tired when you get back to work, but still filling and very tasty.   I've also had the Wood Oven Roasted Pizza, which is excellent and very filling. I swear I didn't think while eating those things that "I can't believe this is owned by Eat 'N Park".  Honest.   For dinner, it's almost as though the atmosphere turns to an older crowd, with a lot of the theater-goers going there before of after the show.   For dinner, I'd recommend the Jamison Farm Lamb Shank, which looks like something you'd find at the LeMont (appearance only - not going to argue quality as I am no chef).   For drinks, this place is top 10 in terms of creativity.  I had lunch there with someone who works for the Eat 'N Park Hospitality Group, who told me that they hired a Mixologist to create new drinks for them.  Where is the line to apply for being a mixologist.  Can you imagine the mixologist's surprise when he confirmed that it was Eat 'N Park calling?   This is not a dig on Eat 'N Park...I'm just saying....  And last but not least, there's the roof deck.  It's a little small, but it's awesome.  There are little patio-like areas for people to sit, and a bar in the back. Decent views of part of the skyline.  Why don't we have more roof-top decks in this town?  Great summer destination.

My first trip to six Penn kitchen. General observation was that some of the details need to be reworked or renewed. Staff was a bit surly. Bartender was not helpful and seemed bothered that we sat at the bar to wait for the others in our reservation. Our waiter shared that same attitude when we were seated. The food was mostly very good. The Ceasar salad was really good. Lamb Bolognese was served very warm and was good. The scallops were also said to be very good. The loser was my gorgonzola gnocchi. It was an incredibly small portion, barely filling the bottom of the large bowl in which it was served. I'm guessing it was over cooked as there were no identifiable gnocci. I identified some meat squares,and a few small cubes of zucchini. Mostly it was mush in a pool of oil. It did have potential but was more like a leftover stew after all of the things you wanted are already eaten. It would have been a good dip for bread if we had been offered some. Mostly decent food, servers with bad attitude or no interest in their customer, maintenance details that could be refreshed, all provide a dining experience that could be significantly better with Management of the details.

We met another couple at Six Penn for dinner and, overall, it was a decent experience.  The food was good and it was gluten free friendly for my wife.  We ordered two appetizers....calamari and the mussels.  Both very good.  I had the signature pork shank and it was very very good.  The only thing that prevented me from giving it more than 3 stars was the service....it was not good at all.  We had to wait for everything including almost 15 minutes for coffee after dinner.  It made us just forget about dessert because we didn't want to kill another 45 minutes waiting.

I would really really love to like this place.  It is next to where I work, and seems to have the right "cost/ambience" ratio for a lot of work related meals.  The ambience is actually fine, the service is fine as well, though it seems like most of the servers are in training at any given moment.  The problem is that the food is really really inconsistent.  I am not particularly picky and I think that I can fairly discern when a dish is not my cup of tea (i.e., uses ingredients that I do not like, e.g., eggplant) vs. just plain awful recipes.  I once ordered crab cakes here.  the dish came with two crab cakes. They were so awful, that I could not eat more than 1/4 of one cake--even though I was hungry and would have like to have eaten them.  They have a couple of nice things like their super thin potato fries, but it is just not a great place.  Again--I wish it were, there is great copper cladding on the outside that is oxidizing nicely, they serve decent sandwiches for lunch so it will probably survive as a business lunch place but I don't think it is up to snuff as a place to look forward to for a meal.  One thing I like about the place is that they have some pots/buckets on top where they grow some of their own produce.  I doubt it is enough for all of their needs, but I like the effort.  What is sad is that despite some really great concepts and ideas, they just do not execute their food in a way that I can recommend.

I struggled with the  star rating on this one and really think it's a three and a half.   Here's the rundown...  Atmosphere.   The place was nice, but the table arrangement seemed a little odd.   There were a few tables that I would not have been happy with.     Drinks.  My cocktails (standard Captain and coke) were good..served with a lime that actually had some juice.     Bread.  The pepper bread was really good.  The other selection was a little dry.  The honey butter was good, but much improved by a little sprinkling of salt.    Soup.   The SOD was a poblano corn chowder, which was delicious.   Perfect temp and consistency, with just a hint of spice.     Entree.   My experience here was kind of mixed.  I ordered the special...redfish and crab over roasted tomatoes, purple beans, and broth.   The broth was amazing!  Rich and flavorful...I wanted to lick the bowl.   The crab and tomatoes were also awesome.   The redfish was not so great.  It was really tough and dry...I needed to use a knife to cut it.   The purple beans were described as "like green beans, but with a purple vein"...which is really not a great description.   Honestly, the beans are more like edamame.  Tender  beans inside a pretty tough pod.   I didn't love them.    Service. So-so.   My cocktails was empty for quite some time and overall, she just seemed a step behind.   Not "bad" by any means, but not exceptional either.

Went for a late dinner after going to a PSO concert across the street. Had reservation and was seated at the first table by the door, the one next to the stairs to second floor. Upon sitting down, we found the table was wobbly. Had some guy come over and stick a piece of folded up paper underneath. Didn't quite fix it but at least it was spilling water anymore.  Noisy environment. OK I understand it was Friday night but still it was noisier than I'd have liked. Prices correctly reflect it's downtown location. However, food was just OK. Ordered crab cakes for some $28 and definitely not the best I've had. Good thing was that it was mostly all crab meat and very little filler but I wasn't impressed by the quality of the meat. Service seemed lacking as well.

Impressive Food and Drink list! And Nice, polish urban spot to visit as a first time Pitts traveler!  I came here in a posse for a early work dinner outing as it was suggested by my boss.  When you enter, you're immediately greeted with long stretch hard wood floors with high ceiling and caramel gold lighting along with the friendly staff. We quickly got seated to our table of 4, then later 5.  I was very impressed with their extensive drink menu as it had a lot of choices! And their farm to table concept is always a winner for me!  APPS: We started with the charcuterie dish. Had a nice blend of meats and cheese. There were 3 types, blue, Brie-like, and harvarti-like, which I preferred.  Soup: I had their seafood soup, it had a nice balance between smoke and savory as it came in a thin texture.   Main: swordfish special: it was over a squash purée paired with a savory multi-bean blend scattered with pickled cauliflower topped with the grilled swordfish. Food presentation was on point; however, it was served cold as it may have came out too early, but thanks to our greet attentive server, she quickly took my dish, apologized and re-heated it and brought it back and I definitely enjoyed.   Other parties had some great looking dishes, which are posted on here.  Overall, great experience!

Oh Six Penn... I wish I wasn't so torn on this review, but sometimes that happens in the Yelp world. First, let me say that the atmosphere is probably my favorite thing about this place. There are 3 levels total. The first level dining/bar area which allows a view of the kitchen, the second level that also has a bar, but is more of an event space and last the roof top which is my favorite space. The roof top is pretty tiny, but they have high top tables, cabanas and a tiny bar area which makes this a cozy spot for brunch or happy hour. Since there are 3 levels they do have an elevator for those that cannot climb steps. This is important because I have been to restaurants that are not handicap accessible.   Lets get down to the nitty gritty and talk about the food. Keep in mind the brunch menu does change, so if you see something you want do not wait because it might not be there. My friends and I had brunch here this past weekend. The roof top is first come first serve, no need for reservations. I ordered a peach bellini ($9) and the pork shoulder hash ($14) which included eggs, toast, asparagus, portobello mushrooms and fingerling potatoes. I was slightly disappointed in my dish. Only because the pork was EXTREMELY fatty and I hate fat. My friend ordered the same thing and hers had no fat on it. Hers also seemed to be cooked more thoroughly than mine. Needless to say I left a skillet filled with pork for our waitress to take back. The other ingredients were extremely tasty on their own without the pork so I scarfed them down instead. I also would like to comment on the fact that their drinks are pretty pricey. A bellini is pretty basic and comes in a tiny champagne glass; charging $9 seems a bit much. If you want to get your money's worth and enjoy boozy drinks, head over to The Urban Tap for their mimosa flights.

Every time I go to Six Penn I'm always surprised the food isn't BETTER than what I had just had.  It's time to face the truth:  this is a lovely and semi swanky restaurant, but the food is not great.  The food is average restaurant food served with a beautiful presentation.  It's over priced but I feel the nice atmosphere kind of evens the pricing out.  Don't even think about coming here during the lunch hour without a reservation.  I'd also recommend letting your server know if you only have an hour for lunch.  It took so long for my chicken breast to come out that I had to get in a to go box and leave.  I do not recommend ordering the grilled chicken breast with pierogies.  Pierogies are ALWAYS good but there were only two of them.  The chicken breast was dry.  Total let down.

Dined at SIx Penn on light up night.  Service was great and the food was very good.  Was disappointed to see veal on the menu. Veal is cruel and should not be on any menu.  Baby cows are confined to extremely confined cages and become anemic to only be slaughtered after a horrific short life.  Definitely, no one at our table ordered veal!

Very sad to see Six Penn go.. I have been to lunch and happy hour numerous times, I was never over impressed until this past weekend. We had a gift certificate to use, so decided to go for dinner. Everything about the experience was awesome. Sarah the  hostess helped find two extra seats for our friends that were a last minute addition. Our server, Kristen was above and beyond fantastic with her service. We hope to follow her wherever she ends up. Our entree choice was the pork shank, and it was so good, we will definitely be back before they close next month. If your're thinking about giving them a chance before they are gone, I recommend it! Still haven't heard a good reason as to why they are really closing...

This is a solid lunch spot, but sometimes it's best to have a reservation. Luckily, they use OpenTable, so you can earn some points.   Their specials are usually pretty good, but my favorite here is the Caesar salad with shrimp. It comes with a few anchovies - you can always have them leave these out, but then we may not be friends anymore.   I've also enjoyed the pizzas here.   I'm only rating Six Penn at 3 stars because it's a tad overpriced and because needing a reservation at lunch is kind of annoying. However, if can you plan ahead, I'd recommend it.

SixPenn Pittsburgh,PA Appetizers: calamari & rock shrimp r no joke no brainer. Artisanal cheeses along with mouth watering pickled veggies but the dark cherries soaked in sweet vermouth & cinnamon, luscious sensuous, orgasmic. Need I say more? Stay tuned...I'm opinionated! Follow me if U dare.

I was pretty impressed by the brunch my friends and I had here. We came in without a reservation with no trouble and were seated in a cushy booth by the window. The space has a modern, trendy look to it but remains cozy and welcoming. I really liked it.  Though it was a bit after 1pm, I still felt compelled to do the brunch cocktail thing so I went with a mimosa http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P4lfCI0WSaVoA2VFdsZRiQ?select=drPh-SgVhCtKaI_C-Rr15g . It was surprisingly not very cold but I enjoyed it anyway.  Our meal was kick-started with a basket of brunch breads - apple bread and raspberry-chocolate scones http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P4lfCI0WSaVoA2VFdsZRiQ?select=j80Rf8c5B-Ke1UTRmZgA4w . They were awesome.   Our server was very pleasant and made some excellent recommendations upon our request. Since one of my friends was realllly hungry, she recommended the breakfast quesadilla because it is very filling. As for her favorite dish, she recommended the Tempura-Fried Bacon BLT.  Tempura-Fried Bacon BLT: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P4lfCI0WSaVoA2VFdsZRiQ?select=DWIVhUSb1UtwM66BNSwBHA Breakfast Quesadilla: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P4lfCI0WSaVoA2VFdsZRiQ?select=DWIVhUSb1UtwM66BNSwBHA Boston Cream Beignets: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P4lfCI0WSaVoA2VFdsZRiQ?select=X4SmYg6HKxEQJvSQnm8Ivg Burger: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P4lfCI0WSaVoA2VFdsZRiQ?select=JHteAM0pMDynO_AE8WBuPA  One of my friends also had a side of the mac and cheese (not pictured).   I ordered the burger and found it to be quite good. It was a little bit overcooked as I had asked for it medium and it was more like well-done but I'm not one to make a big fuss. The potatoes that accompanied the burger were well cooked and the sriracha drizzle added just enough kick.  My friend was totally owned by the breakfast quesadilla. He loved every bite but wasn't able to finish. We all loved the Boston cream beignets. Though my other friend enjoyed her BLT, she found the tempura breading on the bacon to be too overwhelming. After sampling a piece of the bacon, I totally understood. It was way too bread-y.   I would totally come to Six Penn for another meal - like lunch or dinner. I'm a big fan of restaurants who use produce from local and sustainable farmers and was pleasantly surprised to see they buy their lamb from Jamison Farm! Jamison Farm happens to be one of the farmers that comes to the Bethesda (Maryland) Farmer's Market and sell world-class certified humane lamb. Huge huge points for that.   When you visit Six Penn Kitchen, you can expect attentive, unfussy service with delicious food at quite reasonable prices. I'm a fan.

This was without question the worst brunch we have ever had.  It was off to a bad start when it took over 30 minutes to get a $6 biscuit that was burnt.  It ended up taking our table of seven over an hour for us to get our food.  Neighboring tables (including a table of 6) received their food well before we did despite being seated after we had already ordered.  Once the food arrived, I wish that it hadn't.  A very simple plate with effectively just eggs and potatoes was dreadful.  The eggs were overcooked and the food had obviously been sitting out for quite a while, because the food was cold (not just "not hot").  Unfortunately since the food came so late, we didn't have time to even bother with the sending-it-back drill, and candidly the food was so bad, we didn't have any interest in trying again.  The rest of my table didn't have much more luck either.  I'd strongly recommend going somewhere else if you're visiting town.

I have been there before, and had a much better experience this time but I still cannot give it more than three stars.  I just am not that impressed overall.  The service was great, she was both knowledgeable and attentive and helped guide as as far as what she thinks the best items are.  This being our first time there for brunch, it was helpful.  She was right about the Beignets!  YUMMO!  Amazing.  So light and fluffy and the cream was amazing.  My husband seemed to like the deviled eggs (with Ham in honor of the Easter holiday I presume).  He got the Angel food cake french toast with Strawberry cheesecake filling (looked good but too sweet for me) and I got the basic Keystone breakfast.  All good.   The tempura fried bacon was interesting... good though.    Not going to be a spot that we will frequent, but I think it is good.  I just think there are a lot of other options worth exploring in town.
Okay I read the reviews and went to to have a bit for dinner. The prices where out of control in my opinion. I had a bowl of soup that tasted okay.... had a 9 dollar glass of sub par wine and left.

Six Penn Kitchen is just ok for me.  For whatever reason, I'm almost indifferent when it comes to dining out here.  I don't crave it but I do end up here on occassion for lunch because I work downtown.  The menu has a lot of comfort foods on it but for some reason, not a lot of the choices on their menu even interest me.  My go to favorite is the Buffalo Chicken Macaroni and Cheese.  It's the perfect mix of spice and creamy cheese and chicken and not over the top spicy.  It's the only item that I've really enjoyed on the menu.  Everything else is good but nothing really blew my mind.  The lobster mac and cheese was actually a let down.    The service is good: not great, not terrible and the atmosphere is nice.  They have a great open deck area upstairs but unfortunately it's very small and there is limited seating so it doesn't live up to it's full potential.

I stumbled upon this place and decided to give it a try.  I'm eternally grateful for that decision.  My friend and I got right in without a reservation and our server immediately greeted us with water and a smile.  Bread and drinks followed promptly after.      At the recommendation of previous reviewers, I ordered the Buffalo Mac n Cheese.  Oh.my.goodness.   These guys know what they're doing.   I'm not a big fan of the buffalo taste but blended with the cheese and chicken, it was fantastic!   *warning-this dish is not for the calorie counters*.   The cheese was creamy and had a great tang, the pasta was perfectly al dente, and the chicken was nice and tender.  The atmosphere is nice and open yet it was a little loud.  I had to shout at my friend a couple of times.  However, I would still come back for that Mac n Cheese.

I loved this place.   I've been here twice and first got the lamb bolognese and later got the crab and lobster risotto- both dishes were amazing. So flavorful and well prepared, I would say one of the best places I've been to in Pittsburgh.  My boyfriend got the seared duck and he too loved his dish (he got it cooked rare instead of the usual medium). Great flavors and a wonderful atmosphere- this is a great place for a nice date.  I also got the calamari which was great, but I would say to steer away from the salads- nothing too special (or good for that matter). I've had two different types of salad and I would say that you are better off sticking with other appetizers (or the soup)  Using local produce to support local farmers, I appreciate Six Penn Kitchen even MORE- what a great place!  I would definitely recommend this place.  The Almost Arnie is also the best cocktail ever- I usually don't drink (i hate the taste of alcohol, and am a huge lightweight) but this drink is unresistable!!!  I can't wait to go back!
We shared a number of small plates and each was delicious but the polenta with mushrooms and the smoky fingerling potatoes were the best. Try the strawberry basil mojito!

My favorite thing about this place is the rooftop seating! It is first come first served and the space is not very big but it's so nice to eat/drink outside and not feel like you are part of the traffic.   The food is good but not anything I crave. The taco appetizers were delicious. The entree buffalo mac and cheese is good but the side of Mac was a little bland.   I also like the drink selection here. A nice variety of beers and great mix drinks.

I've passed by this place several times and wondered about it- exterior was interesting enough to catch my eye. Place actually had the fee of an older steakhouse. Service was decent. All of the food I tasted was excellent- fried octopus, a water melon salad, and samples from two different cuts of steak. Steak was actually amazing. Beer selection was reasonable but not extravagant...better than average bar of course. Lighting was a little dark..seems like a good place to take your family (parents I mean, didn't really seem geared towards families with children). Business casual dress at least.

The service was a real downer. We had a party of about ten and our waiter was having a little trouble handling everything. We waited about 45 minutes for our cocktails to come out. Several times throughout the night, we would look over at the service area and our food had been sitting there for 10-15 minutes before It was brought to us. Had high hopes for this place because It came highly recommended. Food was decent. 2 stars instead of 1 because my gimlet was pretty solid.

I have eaten here twice before heading over to the Benedum for a show.  Both experiences were fantastic with great service, tasty food and happy taste buds.  The only reason I can't give it 5 stars is because I do feel it is pricey compared to other high end restaurants in the area.  On our first visit, we arrived without reservations.  I wasn't sure what to expect, but they treated us with respect and, thankfully, had several tables available.  The server asked at the beginning of our meal if we had theater tickets because they wanted to ensure that we dined with enough time to still get to the theater.   We started the meal with a bottle of Moscato that was very tasty.  My fiance tried the french onion soup and I had the beet salad.  Both were exceptional.  Entrees were the buffalo mac and cheese and one of the nightly specials.  Again, both were flavorful and had portions that were actually filling.    Even though the entire meal was appealing, the highlight for me was the "carnival" dessert.  You can't go wrong with a treat that features cotton candy, whoopie pies, cracker jacks and other special treats.  It made me smile just looking at it and the grin only continued to grow as I ate the various treats.  The only down side was the crazy sugar rush.  The second time we tried Six Penn was during Restaurant Week.   Same great service and same great food.  The shrimp bisque was tasty (although I found it to be a little salty).  The fillet that came with the "surf and turf" was so tender it literally melted in my mouth.  MMMMM.  They even made one of my least favorite vegetables, Brussels sprouts, tasty!  The crab cake was delicious, too.  Although some may not like it because it is actually made out of a lot of crab compared to the crab cakes at most other places that are mostly breading.  They once again nailed the dessert.  It was a peanut butter cheesecake that was mind blowing.  Creamy, tasty, sweet.  MMMM.  I almost ordered a piece to go so I could have some the next day.  I enjoy Six Penn, but with the high price tag, it will have to remain someplace that I visit for only an occasional treat.

I came here for brunch before the steelers game with a few friends. I had an omelette and my friend had scrambled eggs with toast potatoes sausage and bacon and we tried the donut. The donut was not cooked , literally not cooked at all. We asked for butter and other condiments  and he never returned with them. He was basically nonexistent. Also, everything was extremely salty! Don't eat the potatoes, they made me sick. This was my second experience here and I definitely won't be returning.

I've only gone to the rooftop bar happy hour at Six Penn and if you can score one of the two tents up there with comfy couch seating, then you're golden. They have decent cocktails and a slew of unhealthy but yummy appetizers. The service was a bit uneven, but it was a gorgeous late afternoon well spent. Be aware that traffic and parking might be issues in downtown Pittsburgh, especially if there's a game going on. I parked at the $8 garage across the street and I'm glad I did because afterwards, I got to see the game end fireworks from the parking garage which turns out to be a perfect vantage point, especially from the roof of the garage.

Amazing dinner!  Came to town to visit and stopped by Point State Park before wandering around town looking for a fun place to dine.  It started pouring as we were considering eating there so we kind of had no choice but to get out of the rain. Staff is very friendly.  I don't know what these other people are talkin about the staff being rude.  Ordered the soup of the day (roasted red pepper and corn bisque with bacon and scallions) and it was amazing!  My drink was a cherry cayenne sour and had a very uniquely spicy flavor. Crackling pork shank for dinner was huge and accompanied by bacon sauerkraut mashed and a delicious apple purée.  Individual apple pie for dessert.  Yum!  They use local meats and produce which makes a huge difference.  Entire meal with drinks, apps and dessert came to $70 for two people.  Six Penn is a must try!
The KimChee bowl...please take off menu.  As a half Korean I was sorely disappointed...and the shrimp "etouffe" was no where close. I dropped $80 here and expected much more.

Great presentation. Great service. Atmosphere very sophisticated.  The food was bland. Everything was WAY overpriced.  Other reviews stated that the restaurant was casual. It is far from casual. You go best dressed or you stick out like a sore thumb...trust me.

We kept on coming back here because it is so very convenient as a post-concert hangout. My dining experience there, sadly, has declined further.   The menu still attempts to lure you in with intriguing descriptions of ingredients and preparations that demand a more competent chef than whom they have. More unsatisfying, though is their recent tendency to cut corners and short change you. To wit:  1. The bread "basket" is now a thin slice of bread the size of a 3"x5" index card for each diner. Sure, you can ask for more, but they will only dole out another measly "basket"... whenever they get around to it.  2. I ordered a salad that was described as "baby oak leaves with gorgonzola, bosc pear, and walnuts." The first time it arrived, there was no cheese or nuts, just a lot of leaves and one slice of pear. The second time around, I got a slightly smaller mound of leaves with the missing cheese and nuts, but the one actual slice of pear has now been reduced to two end pieces -- pear skins the size of quarters.   3. Because the menu had slim vegetarian pickings, my companion asked for the vegetable and pasta sides from their short rib dish. At the end of the meal, we were unpleasantly surprised to find that she has been charged for the full price of the meat dish. The kitchen's response "we gave her more pasta to make up the difference."  Because our table ordered both the meat version and the meatless version, we could see that the meatless version didn't have *that* much more pasta. Per ounce, that might have been the most expensive bit of pasta in all of greater Pittsburgh.  In summary, Six Penn is not the worst place to grab a bite if you are already in the cultural district, but you have to be willing to overpay for a so-so experience.

I had never been to Six Penn before I came for a Yelp Elite event. From the very beginning, the staff set the mood of the evening. We were greeted with champagne as we took our seats. There were wine glasses that corresponded with every one of the 7-courses. The manager came out for every course and explained the dish and the wine pairing, as well as why the dish was chosen.  The first course was chicken consomme. The broth was light, as it should be. The vegetables were not too soft or too firm. The second-course was tartare. I was nervous about eating tartare but it was delicious. The plate was presented beautifully. The third-course was foie gras, chicken I believe. It was my first time having it and another item I was nervous about, but it was delicious. It tasted like meat, but just soft. It had a nice char to it that gave it another layer of flavor. The fourth course was a braised shoulder and chop of lamb. It was paired with a fantastic lentil dish. For dessert, we had a unique dessert that had pistachios, a berry sauce, and a globe made up of something that was delicious but I don't actually remember what it was made of.  The decor is somewhat upscale, so I wouldn't come here in jeans and a T-shirt. I would come back again for sure.

Went for dinner on National Martini Day. Ordered "Meg's Martini" referenced in an e-mail newsletter from 6 Penn. Don't ever do that. Weak, flavorless, uninspiring. Does a great disservice to the holiday.  FOOD! Now we're talking artistic presentations. Excellent bread. Yummy, creative appetizers. Different. Delicious. My wife's suggestion for our next visit: a couple of appetizers and a shared bottle of wine. The selections were that good.   Lamb shank and trout. Both were first rate. No little, prissy plates with two bites of food. Real Pittsburgh size meals. Trout was big, flavorful and displayed on the platter unlike any trout I have ever seen. Usually a flat, dried out piece of fish lays on the plate in a visually boring way. Not at 6 Penn. Order the trout. You will be pleasantly surprised. Better be hungry!  Lamb shank must be a signature dish. At the end of her dinner, my wife did actually leave the bone on the plate. Everything else was gone! 6 Penn has an excellent kitchen: empty plates prove that.  Service was very good. Good range of prices on a somewhat obscure wine list. Restaurant is noisy... echos a lot.  For downtown restaurant visitors, we feel that our experience at 6 Penn was much better than our visit to Elements. Better service. Better food.   We're going back for the appetizers and wine!  Enjoy.

Had a great brunch here! My bf and I  started with a tasty Bloody Mary and mimosa. We thought so much sounded great, so we decided to order one smoked salmon crepe and a poached egg which was topped with the spicy Bloody Mary mix and was served with popcorn grits. I've never had anything like these grits, they really taste like popcorn, something I'm not fond of, but the flavor worked in this dish. And the creamy seafood crepe was delicious as well, we couldn't decide which was better. I'd definitely come back if I lived in pittsburgh, it made for a great Sunday brunch.

I enjoy outside dining wherever it's available.  It's even more fabulous when you have the opportunity to sit atop of a high rise building in the heart of downtown Pittsburgh.  Seating here is first- come, first- serve, and you seat yourself.  A fun place to go before attending any of the shows in the cultural district.  Plenty of good drink and food options.  However, I must mention that my last visit became a bit puzzling when the server kept announcing it was going to rain.  This phrase was repeated at least 5 times during our visit. My friend and I ordered our drinks and asked to see a food menu.  His first response was :" It's going to rain".    The menus were delivered, and he re-affirmed that it was going to rain.  Mind you, the rooftop was filled with other patrons.  I finally replied that if it rains we will go inside.  He replied that our tab would not transfer to the inside.  He left and came back for our order and then announced that the latest radar shows a rain storm moving in.  I finally said we will use an umbrella if we need to!  Our order was placed, an updated weather report was given, and before we knew it, our food was delivered  within a timely fashion.  We were very pleased with the presentation and taste of our food, along with the fact that we no longer had to worry or hear about the latest forecast. (By the way, the rain never appeared during our meal, but did so much later in the evening.)  Six Penn will still be on my list as the place to go for outside dining anytime I am attending a show, however, I might make sure there isn't a cloud or two in the sky before choosing to do so.

It seems that this place may have been better in the past based on friends' experiences.  I went as part of a work party.  There was a set menu that seemed promising.  The caesar salad was fantastic although I was not given the option to hold the whole anchovies, which is standard operating protocol at any American restaurant that serves it with anchovies.  But moving along, the salmon was lackluster and the portion miniscule.  The saving grace was the delicious and refreshing gin drink, which uses wigle whiskey's ginever, which is the only reason for 2 stars.  The cranberry bread pudding for desert was a small portion (and I appreciate small portions usually) and overcooked. Lastly, parking is partially comped, which for an expensive restaurant in a city with already cheap parking should be free especially considering it was self-park and not valet. I can't see any reason to return.

I must admit I was disappointed! I made reservations to celebrate our anniversary.  I made them aware was a special night when I called.  When we arrived we were seated promptly.  The food was decent, the atmosphere loud and dark as expected-- we enjoyed being by the kitchen. The server was nice but didn't seem interested in making the night special for us. I felt like his opinion was "it is all good" rather than "this particular meal is amazing!" He didn't acknowledge our anniversary-- or ask if we wanted dessert at the end of our meal.    We asked if we could have a drink at the rooftop and he informed us we couldn't have service up there... We went up and it was empty.  It was a little bit of a downer! The meals (prime rib and lamb bolognese pasta) were good but we agreed nothing made us want to go back other than location and roof top (closed) bar!  I would love to tell you about our amazing drinks and dessert, but I can't. There are soooo many amazing Pittsburgh restaurants... I would say head down Sixth Avenue and find another one!

None of us were really hungry when we ended up here.  We were trying to kill time and pretty much just had drinks and appetizers (buffalo chicken macaroni, short ribs), but what we had was pretty good.  We were seated immediately, our waitress was friendly and attentive, and the decor was nice.  Some of the customers were dressed, others wearing Steelers jerseys.  A nice, unpretentious spot that I'd go to again.

Went here for dinner on New Years Eve.  We were passing through Pittsburgh for the night and didn't want a fancy dinner or to spend a ton on a "special" menu.  Six Penn served their regular menu and had some specials. But they didn't seem to jack up prices for NYE. We started with the house made pretzels and they were excellent.  I had the short ribs for my entree and they were very good.  They have a good wine selection. Overall an enjoyable meal!

I love this place.  The menu is a twist on regular food, I can't get enough of the buffalo mac and cheese, and the pork shank.  Nice, modern atmosphere, convenient to the downtown cultural district, and reasonably priced. The only thing I wish they had was good bread.  The bread there is baked there, but it's not good.

After traveling most of the day, via plane, for work, you want to find a good place to have your first meal in the city. Although some downtown digs in cities across the country can come across too pretentious or too hole in the wall (not if there isn't awesome food at both extremes), Six Penn Kitchen is a great balance to that - did I mention a roof to bar with late night happy hour?  The locally grown food was great. My coworkers had a variety of things that were all great. We all started off with a mixed salad with a Dijon herb vinaigrette that was light and fresh. My thick cut pork chop over molasses beans and sautéed string beans were very tasty. The bbq chicken was a huge portion and the burger was a solid choice. The aroma of the cedar planks and wood chips grilling permeated throughout the restaurant, leaving you to ask, "What's on the grill?"  Even better was the after dinner drinks on the roof top. Although small, the roof top bar had a mix of bench and cushioned seating. The happy hour specials on well drinks, domestics, and wine went through the night - 9-11pm.   Best Highlight: Locally grown products in all their food.  Low point: The rooftop bar isn't as big as one would hope, but this isn't the Standard in LA.
Pork shank is incredible, mashed potatoes with sauerkraut and bacon below. Service was mediocre, that's why they fell short of 5 stars...cool restaurant.

Food: 3 stars Atmosphere: 3 stars Service: 1 star  We came here on a Tuesday night after seeing the PSO across the road. Already full on hors d'oeuvres, we decided to finish the night with some dessert.  I wish we hadn't gone. The waitress kept on ignoring our table. We finally got to order after sitting there for fifteen minutes. When we told her we wanted the dessert menu, she gave us a look. Finally, she split the bill wrong and didn't bother to check up on us.  As for the desserts, they were truly lackluster. Presentation is a 3.5, but the taste is more like a 2. Everything tasted unidimensional: sweet, or creamy, or revolting. Nothing stood out to me, and you'd imagine something would at an average price of $7 per dessert. For reference, we had the cheesecake, the special (a poor rendition of smores), and the apple thing (texture was way off, and lukewarm).  Don't go.

I've been here a few times for lunch and for drinks.  I've enjoyed the experience overall.  I will say that I only get 1-2 drinks here for happy hour and then usually head somewhere else a little bit more affordable and jumping.    As for lunch, I absolutely love and highly recommend the "Lo mein noodle salad, crispy vegetable spring roll, bean sprouts; peanut hoisin sauce" - the noodles are cold so don't be surprised.  If you like Asian inspired food, then you'll probably enjoy this dish.  Every time that I go for lunch, this is my go to dish.  I've had some of the other stuff, but the fact that I can't remember what they were should be telling enough.    It's not a bad place to check out, but it's not top on my list for food or drinks overall.

This was my last meal in Pittsburgh...and it happens to be the 2nd best meal I had in 7 days.  I ordered the pork loin.... But that was only 1part of pork three way.  There was a mini pork pot pie and fried pork belly.  It was pure pork heaven.  The only portion that was just OK was the pork pie.     We also ordered the pretzel bites...come on, I come all the way to Pittsburgh and don't do pretzel... The  cheesy dipping sauce was the way to go.    The only bad thing was the downstairs men's room.  There was only a toilet.  The room smells clean, but the trash can needed emptying and paper towels picked up from the floor.  This is the reason I only have 4 stars... I wish I could do 4.5

Six Penn is a fun place. A very good place to drink and a pretty good place to eat.  First off, the place is very cool and the menu has some great options. I loved the appetizers and also liked the the cocktails. My pork dish was pretty darn salty and the side dishes were also a little heavy on the sodium.  Overall, good place to eat downtown. Would love to have the chef read this....

This review is purely for the Jamison Farm Lamb Bolognese with Pappardelle, Feta, and Roasted Tomato's.  Even as I write this I am slightly embarrassed. I was in Pittsburgh for all of 6 days and I went here not once, but twice. It was so good! I got the Jamison Farm Lamb Bolognese BOTH times. Lamb was so tender and had great flavor. I am not sure why there was "potato chips" on top of the dish but they were wonderful too. If I had found this place earlier I hate to say I may have returned again for fear I would never get to eat this wonderful meal again. This was my first trip to Pittsburgh and i didn't know when I would be returning.   I sat a the bar both times so I cannot speak for the service at the tables. Bartender was friendly but more interested in some sports event on TV. Which was fine I guess.Nice Wine list to select from. Large windows to look out to the people walking by.   Would definitely recommend checking this place out in your in town.

Delicious!!! Our group of 3 decided to tryout their rooftop dining on a nice sunny summer day. We ordered: tilapia special, short rub meat loaf, fish and chips, mojito, whiskey mule  Everything was amazing and the service from Mark was right up there too. He was attentive and friendly. he filled us in on the happy hour and we will be back!

I was on a business trip and didn't have much to do while I was in Pittsburgh. I absolutely love mac and cheese so I heard this place had one of the best and I thought I would try it out. It was freezing when I walked from my hotel to the restaurant so I wasn't exactly happy when I arrived. But the service was absolutely terrible. I sat in the bar since I was by myself. I asked for beer and was rudely given an answer like I knew nothing about what to drink. I knew exactly what I wanted to eat so I ordered the Buffalo Chicken Mac and Cheese right away. It didn't take long to get it and it was actually really good but spicy and it took me a couple times to ask my server for water and I asked for more bread (to cool my taste buds) and never got it. They were so eager to get me out of there they brought the check right away. The food was great. Beer was good but service and atmosphere was terrible. I ventured out in the cold and just wanted to sit and relax but I ended up being rushed out. I wouldn't go back, maybe only for take-out.

I have been to six penn multiple times and normally its good food and ok service. However this past Friday service was absolutely terrible they messed up multiple orders and the food wasnt even good. I tried the summer bbq and everything was overcooked. The ribs had next to no meat. I will have to say if you are going to give this place a try go for the cracklin pork shank. Now for the service, it is some of the worst we have ever experienced. They messed up orders and we couldn't even get the waiter's attention to tell him that he gave us the wrong thing. Instead of removing the item from our bill he only reduced the item by 50%. All and all the food isn't terrible, however for the price I expect better quality and service. I have had similar, if not better tasting food at other new up and coming spots in Pittsburgh. Unless they make some major changes to service levels we will not be returning.

I ate here this past Sunday for Brunch with my girlfriend and two of her friends that were in from Baltimore.  The restaurant was busy whenever we got there and we were asked if we minded sitting on the rooftop under a shaded area which we did not.  Upon getting to the rooftop we were escorted to a little cabana type shelter which provided ample shade to our group.  It was originally comfortable but with the temperatures climbing into the 90's on this day, it was hot by the end of our meal.  The set up of the cabana was also more conducive to having cocktails than eating a full brunch as it was sans table or anything high enough to comfortably eat off of while sitting down.  Our group decided to start off our brunch by ordering the boston cream beignets.  They came out failrly quickly and were plated nicely with lots of chocolate and cream.  I was not too big a fan of the taste though.  It's not that they were bad but they were not nearly as good as the ones that I have had in New Orleans.  For my entree I decided upon the frittata with lemon aoili and pickle salad while also ordering a side of tempura bacon for our table to share.  The first bite of my frittata was awesome as it had some pickle, artichoke and aioli which gave a nice tartness to it.
